chapters.title: Definition
chapters.text: An asset is a resource with economic value that an individual, corporation, or country owns or controls with the expectation that it will provide a future benefit. Assets are reported on a company's balance sheet and are bought or created to increase a firm's value or benefit the firm's operations.

chapters.title: Relevance
chapters.text: An asset can be thought of as something that, in the future, can generate cash flow, reduce expenses, or improve sales, regardless of whether it's manufacturing equipment or a patent.

chapters.title: Current Assets
chapters.text:
Current assets are assets that are expected to be converted to cash within a year. Current assets are separated from other resources because a company relies on its current assets to fund ongoing operations and pay current expenses.

Examples of current assets include:

1)Cash and cash equivalents

2)Accounts receivable

3)Prepaid expenses

4)Inventory

5)Marketable securities

chapters.title: Noncurrent Assets
chapters.text:
Noncurrent assets are those that are considered long-term, where their full value won't be recognized until at least a year. Since noncurrent assets have a useful life for a very long time, companies spread their costs over several years. This process helps avoid huge losses during the years when capital expansions occur. Examples of non-current assets include: 1)Land

2)Property, plant, and equipment (PP&E)

3)Trademarks

4)Long-term investments

5)Goodwill

chapters.title: Difference between Current & Noncurrent Assets
chapters.text: The key difference between current and noncurrent assets and liabilities, which are all listed on the balance sheet, is their timeline for use or payment.
